dt: {bc}{d_link|hackneyed|hackneyed} or boring from much use {bc}not fresh or original

pt: {sc}trite{/sc} {sc}hackneyed{/sc} {sc}stereotyped{/sc} {sc}threadbare{/sc} mean lacking the freshness that evokes attention or interest. {sc}trite{/sc} applies to a once effective phrase or idea spoiled from long familiarity.

pt.t: "you win some, you lose some" is a {it}trite{/it} expression

pt: {sc}hackneyed{/sc} stresses being worn out by overuse so as to become dull and meaningless.

pt.t: all of the metaphors and images in the poem are {it}hackneyed{/it}

pt: {sc}stereotyped{/sc} implies falling invariably into the same pattern or form.

pt.t: views of minorities that are {it}stereotyped{/it} and out-of-date

pt: {sc}threadbare{/sc} applies to what has been used until its possibilities of interest have been totally exhausted.

pt.t: a mystery novel with a {it}threadbare{/it} plot

quotes.t: Experts are always unique (their {qword}tritest{/qword} pronouncements are packaged as news) …
Its wares are soiled with frequent handling; its styles are so hackneyed, {qword}trite{/qword}, and homogeneous, they constitute a single style …
The wrong sort of built environment, she argued, wrecked the social fabric of cities. This view seems almost {qword}trite{/qword} today, but in the 1960's it was insurgent.

et: Latin {it}tritus{/it}, from past participle of {it}terere{/it} to rub, wear away {ma}{mat|throw:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: hackneyed or boring from much use : not fresh or original
